text: I love this soundtrack, is stands as one of my favorites to this day.  I listen to it at work when I'm repairing computers mostly.  The atmosphere of it....I can really focus on my work with this playing in the background....must be from the hundred of hours I spent with the game. I get shit done when this plays. hehe

author: Nation of Masturbation

text:
Ah, Diablo....
This was the first hardcore game I ever played, having watched my dad play it and finally, after a month or so, being able to play it. For me, Diablo always will represent being confronted with fears (the arachnids deserving...special mention), seeing things happen to people that just shouldn't even be thought of, and doing everything in your power to make sure others don't have to face this, too.
This track sums all that up nicely.
author: felixvelariusbos

text: All these years later, it still creeps me out.
author: SkeletonBill

text: For me, Diablo's soundtrack is the best ever composed, every track fits perfectly with the ambience, especially this one (caves) and the one of the monastery/ catacombs levels. Oh, and of course the two tracks of Act 4. I simply love this game!
author: Jake the Dog

text:
What made both Diablo games great is that because of the great ambient music and the crazy numbers of enemies you're fighting you really DO feel that you're down in the creepy, creepy caves combating against the endless hordes of Hell.

It's all very happy and upbeat, really.

text:
I totally reinstalled Diablo 2 after hearing the Tristram track earlier on this monster playlist.

Which reminds me, was there some reason they seperated the online and offline characters? I always assumed it was because offline you could use cheats or something (as in Starcraft) but I recently discovered that you cannot (I don't use them so I hadn't bothered checking until now).  Anyone know why I can't take my online character offline to prevent it from expiring?
